data.title: Short Call | Is this correction finally over? Tata Chemicals, Asian Paints in focus
data.description:
Short Call.

From January 27, the benchmark Nifty 50 index has soared over 4 percent, and settled above the 10 percent correction line. Does this mean the correction is over?

Let's look at the facts.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

1.Jefferies noted that in the past decade, 9 times out of 10, Nifty corrected alongside the EM index suggesting high global linkages. The MSCI EM Index corrected by 12 percent from Oct'24 peak thru to Jan bottom but the index is already up ~5 percent from the January bottom.

2. The market correction has been ongoing for 126 days, making it the 2nd longest of the 10 corrections in the last 10 years. Markets have corrected 10 times in the past 10 years.

3. Valuations: The brokerage noted that valuation indicators at 10-year average level now. Nifty is currently trading at 18.8x 1-yr fwd PE, which is still 3-4 percent above its 10-year average, but it has moderated from earlier highs. On a yield gap basis (Bond yield - Earnings yield), the valuation is now at 10-yr avg (145 bps). Historically, this has been a strong indicator of future returns, noted Jefferies.

4. The Indian rupee has been steadily weakening. However, the outlook can change materially to the positive, if DXY traces back to the September 2024 level. President Donald Trump wants a weaker USD and in his first term, DXY declined by 14 percent over the first 14 months, noted Jefferies.

So does this mean the ongoing correction has now come to an end? Well, that, only time and the markets can tell!

Tata Chemical (Rs 918.35, -3%)

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Reported underwhelming Q3 numbers.

Bull Case: Soda ash prices are expected to scale a turnaround going ahead. Further, this quarter was hit by a one-time exceptional loss, on account of expenses related to employee termination benefits, decommissioning of plant and machinery, and other closure-related costs following the cessation of soda ash production at the Lostock plant in Northwich, UK.
Bear Case: In the short-term, the current demand-supply adverse situation is likely to persist but should improve and stabilise over the long term driven by growth sectors based on sustainability trend, said the management.

Asian Paints (Rs 2,355, +2.7%)

Net profit of Rs 1,128 cr in Q3, margin and volume beat estimates

Bull case: Despite near-term headwinds, Asian Paints' strong brand equity and leadership position in the decorative paints segment give it a long-term edge. Management anticipates a return to revenue growth in the coming quarters, suggesting that the worst of the slowdown may be behind the company.

Bear case: The company is grappling with its fourth straight quarter of revenue decline, with a deteriorating product mix further exacerbating the issue. Additionally, subdued demand and rising competitive pressure may continue to weigh on margins, making a swift recovery uncertain.

(With inputs from Lovisha.)
data.author: MoneyControl

data.title: Asian Paints Q3 show fails to impress brokerages, stress in urban demand to continue for few quarters
data.description:
Goldman Sachs reiterated its 'sell' call, with a price target of Rs 2,275 per share.

  • Watchlist
  • Portfolio
  • Message
  • Set Alert
 
 
live
  • bselive
  • nselive
Volume
Todays L/H
More

India's largest paints player Asian Paints Ltd.'s earnings show for the quarter failed to impress analysts, as most maintained their bearish calls or trimmed their bullish target prices.

Asian Paints reported a 23 percent drop in net profit at Rs 1,128 crore for the quarter ended December 31, 2024 hit by weak festive season demand. The paint maker reported net profit of Rs 1,475 crore in the year-ago period.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

The company's revenue declined 6 percent to Rs 8,549 crore in Q3FY25 as against Rs 9,103 crore in Q3FY24. The December quarter marked the fourth consecutive quarter of revenue decline for Asian Paints. However, the management foresees revenue growth returning within the next few quarters.

The paints major saw muted demand as a result of the weak festive season and lagging urban demand. Although the operating margins improved on a sequential basis but on a yearly basis, the margins remained impacted due to increased distribution expenses.

In the near term, the company remain cautiously optimistic on a recovery in demand conditions while it shall continue to invest in its brand and focus on innovation and customer centricity. Further, volume growth is likely to be in single-digits going forward, while EBITDA margins are likely to be 18–20 percent. Some softening is anticipated in raw material prices

Follow our live blog to catch all the updates

International brokerage Goldman Sachs maintained its 'sell' call, with a price target of Rs 2,275, as the near-term demand is likely to remain subdued. Further, the increased competitive intensity is likely to rise.

The demand outlook remains weak along with downtrading by customers, which led to an adverse product mix, noted Nuvama Institutional Equities. The rural outlook remains strong, but urban shall pick up only after two more quarters. The brokerage kept its 'buy' rating intact, but trimmed its estimates and target price to Rs 3,000 per share, down from Rs 3,185 apiece.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad
Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

data.title: Gold hits record high as US-China trade war stokes haven demand
data.description:
That came after President Donald Trump hit Chinese imports with a 10% tariff the day before, prompting a swift but more targeted retaliation from Beijing.

Gold rose to a record high, after advancing by almost 1% in the previous session, as the opening salvos of the US-China trade war stoked haven demand.

Bullion reached an all-time peak of $2,849.05 an ounce on Wednesday. That came after President Donald Trump hit Chinese imports with a 10% tariff the day before, prompting a swift but more targeted retaliation from Beijing.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

The response from China was relatively muted compared to Trump’s first term, when Beijing hit back with tariffs that were almost on par with the US, but there’s still plenty of trepidation about the impact on the world’s two biggest economies. Markets are also waiting to see if there are any ripple effects for US monetary policy if tariffs reignite inflation.

Adding to the uncertain outlook, Trump proposed that the US take over the Gaza Strip and assume responsibility for reconstructing the war-torn territory, during a press conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The precious metal should benefit from increasing unease about what lies ahead, although may lose some of its luster if interest rates stay high.

A gauge of the dollar fell, extended losses following a US jobs report on Tuesday that pointed to a gradual slowdown in the labor market. A weaker greenback makes commodities like gold cheaper for most buyers.

“Who doesn’t like a safe-haven in this scenario?,” said Charu Chanana, a strategist at Saxo Capital Markets Pte.. “No good news on US-China talks and more geopolitical angst with the Gaza news would continue to provide a further boost to gold, irrespective of where the US dollar goes.”

Spot gold rose 0.1% to $2,844.82 an ounce as of 9:17 a.m. in Singapore. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index was down 0.1%, after a 0.7% loss on Tuesday. Silver and palladium dipped, while platinum edged higher.

Trade-war fears had jolted precious-metals markets even before Trump went ahead with the tariffs on China. US prices of gold and silver have surged above international benchmarks in recent weeks, prompting dealers and traders to rush huge volumes of the metals into America before any tariffs take effect. The chaos also led to a spike in lease rates for gold and silver — the return that holders of metal in London’s vaults can get by loaning it out on a short-term basis.

data.description:
NLC India

NLC India share price will remain in focus on February 5 following the company emerged as a successful bidder for new Patrapara South Coal Mine in Angul District of Odisha.

The coal mine block is having a total geological reserve of 720.87 million tonnes (Approximately) with a peak rated capacity of 12 million tonnes per annum.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

This is the third commercial coal mine for the company, crossing 100 million tonnes of mining capacity commitment in line with its corporate plan 2030, company said.

Catch all the market action on our live blog

The company had reported 166.8 percent jump in its net profit at Rs 668.09 crore against Rs 250.42 crore in December 2023.

The revenue from operations was up 39.4 percent at Rs 4,411.41 crore against Rs 3,164.40 crore, YoY.

In January, the company's subsidiary, NLC India Renewables, has signed a Joint Venture Agreement with Assam Power Distribution Company for the development of a solar power project in Assam.

data.title: Alkem Laboratories shares in focus on launching new product in skincare segment
data.description:
Alkem Laboratories

  • Watchlist
  • Portfolio
  • Message
  • Set Alert
 
 
live
  • bselive
  • nselive
Volume
Todays L/H
More

Alkem Laboratories share price will remain in focus on February 5 after the company launched Kojiglo serum in India for managing facial hyperpigmentation, which is suitable for all skin types.

The company is the first Indian company to introduce a liposomal serum with Duo-Lipo technology.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

This innovative formulation combines cutting-edge ingredients such as liposomal azelaic acid, liposomal 4-butyl resorcinol, tranexamic acid, alpha arbutin, and niacinamide, making it a first of its kind in India to have a Duo-Lipo technology, it added.

This advanced serum encapsulates the active ingredients in a liposomal form to enhance penetration in the skin and deliver targeted action, company said.

Catch all the market action on our live blog

A meeting of the board of directors of the company is scheduled to be held on February 7, 2025, to consider and approve the standalone and consolidated unaudited financial results of the company for the quarter and nine months ended 31st December, 2024.

The board will also consider and approve interim dividend for financial year 2024-2025.

The company had set February 14 as a record date for the purpose of payment of interim dividend for financial year 2024-2025, subject to declaration.

data.title: First Tick: Here are the top global cues for today’s trade
data.description:
Market Today

Indian benchmark indices Sensex and Nifty 50 are likely to see a positive start on February 5, tracking cues from GIFT Nifty trading around 23,846.50, a short while ago this morning.

Track the latest updates on GIFT Nifty right here on Moneycontrol.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

India's benchmark indices, Sensex and Nifty, surged 1.8 percent on the back of strong gains in capital goods, banking, energy, and auto stocks. Market sentiment remained upbeat ahead of the Reserve Bank of India's bi-monthly policy announcement scheduled for Friday.

At close, the Sensex climbed 1.81% (1,397.07 points) to 78,583.81, while the Nifty advanced 1.6% (378.20 points) to 23,739.25.

Here is how financial markets across the globe fared overnight:

GIFT Nifty (Gains)

The GIFT Nifty is a trading higher, indicating a positive start for the day. Nifty futures were trading at 23,846.50at around 07:15 am IST.

Asian Equities (Gain)

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Asian stocks rose as traders navigated their way through a US-China trade war and earnings from Wall Street’s big tech companies. Chinese markets are set to reopen.

US Equities (Gain)

US stocks rallied on Tuesday, while gold reached new highs as global trade jitters kept investors guessing.

All three major US stock indexes gained momentum after last-minute negotiations resulted in one-month reprieves on President Donald Trump's 25% levies against Canada and Mexico.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 134.13 points, or 0.30%, to 44,556.04, the S&P 500 rose 43.31 points, or 0.72%, to 6,037.88 and the Nasdaq Composite rose 262.06 points, or 1.35%, to 19,654.02.

US Bond Yield (Up)

US 10-Year Treasury yield rose 18 bps at 4,51 percent and US 2-Year Treasury was up 15 bps at 4.22 percent in the early Wednesday trade.

Dollar Index (Flat)

The U.S. dollar edged lower as President Donald Trump’s tariff threats were interpreted more as a negotiating tactic rather than an end goal, a day after he suspended planned measures against Mexico and Canada.

Asian currencies (Up)

Asian currencies were trading mostly higher in the early trade on Wednesday.

Crude (Gains)

In commodities, oil edged higher despite  concerns that the trade war would hurt global growth outweighed the announcement of reinforced sanctions on Iran

Gold (Flat)

Gold rose to a record high, after advancing by almost 1% in the previous session, as the opening salvos of the US-China trade war stoked haven demand.

Fund Flow Action

After remaining net sellers for the 23 sessions, the Foreign institutional investors (FIIs) turned net buyers on February 4, as they bought equities worth Rs 809 crore. On the contrary, 35 domestic institutional investors (DIIs) turned net sellers after remaining net buyers for the last 35 sessions, as they sold equities worth Rs 430 crore.

Hope you're all set for today's trade, we wish you a profitable day ahead.

data.author: MoneyControl

data.title: MC Interview: Growth impulse from Budget positive for FY26, focus now on corporate earnings, says Kotak AMC's Shibani Kurian
data.description:
Shibani Sircar Kurian is the Senior Executive Vice President, Fund Manager & Head – Equity Research at Kotak Mahindra AMC

For equity markets, the growth impulse from the Budget should be positive for FY2025-26 though the focus would now shift back to the delivery of corporate earnings, said Shibani Sircar Kurian, Senior Executive Vice President, Fund Manager & Head – Equity Research at Kotak Mahindra AMC in an interview to Moneycontrol.

Notwithstanding the near-term challenges on the macro- economic front, she remains optimistic about India's structural growth outlook in the medium to long run. India, in FY25, remains one of the fastest growing large economies of the world and is expected to remain so in FY26 as well, said Shibani with more than 19 years of experience in the capital markets.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Do you think the budget has given a strong support to the equity market that was under bear pressure since September?

The first full year budget of Modi 3.0, provides the right ingredients for laying the foundation to help propel India to the next leg of growth. The Budget FY26 delivers on the 3Cs supporting middle class consumption, increase in capex through centre, state and PSU allocations even while continuing to walk on the path of fiscal consolidation.

The budget delivered more than expectations in terms of the measures announced aimed at providing impetus to consumption by supporting the urban and middle class demand. This would, in turn, provide more disposable income in the hands of the consumer, thereby boosting consumption. Importantly, the budget support comes at an opportune time when consumption, especially at the bottom of the pyramid and urban consumption were seeing muted trends even while there have been some signs of revival in rural demand.

We have seen a well-coordinated fiscal and monetary response to supporting growth, while ensuring macro stability as well. In this context all eyes would be on the Monetary Policy to be announced later in the week. For equity markets, the growth impulse from the budget should be positive for FY2025-26 though the focus would now shift back to the delivery of corporate earnings. Recent correction in Indian equities over the past few months has resulted in large cap valuations correcting to long term average levels. Relative valuation comfort is more for large cap segment vis-à-vis mid/ small caps.

Do you expect the RBI to begin monetary easing in the February meeting?

The RBI monetary policy to be announced in February 2025 will be critical in shaping interest rate trends in India and monetary policy direction under the new RBI Governor. We believe that the current domestic rate cut cycle would be a shallow one, even while the timing of the rate cut would depend on data points such as the inflation trajectory along with global trends on monetary policy (especially the US Fed). Importantly, the focus of the Central Bank has shifted towards liquidity management with the recently announced measures.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Amidst persistently tight system liquidity (the last LAF print was a deficit of above Rs 3.1 lakh crore), RBI has announced a slew of measures to ease liquidity and reduce part of the deficit. Banking system liquidity has been persistently in a deficit zone since mid-December 2024, after being comfortably in surplus during July-November 2024. The core liquidity (net LAF, including the governments cash balance) had also turned deficit for the first time since July 2019. Thus, steps for liquidity management, would play an important role in improving the lending conditions in the economy.

Is the economy experiencing a cyclical slowdown or just a temporary one?

Notwithstanding the near-term challenges on the macro- economic front, we remain optimistic about India's structural growth outlook in the medium to long run. India, in FY25, remains one of the fastest growing large economies of the world and is expected to remain so in FY26 as well.

Do you think the market will consolidate for a couple of months before regaining strong momentum in FY26?

We continue to be structurally positive on the Indian equity markets in the medium to long term even while we would have to navigate the near term volatility. The recent volatility has been a mix of global and domestic factors. On the domestic front, the Q2FY25 earnings season was a muted one with earnings growth in mid-single digits and the expectations for earnings growth for Q3 also remains in the 6-8% range for the Nifty companies.

Hence, while Indian markets have outperformed in the last 3 years, one must moderate near term return expectations even as the structural opportunity for Indian equities remains intact. Largecaps continue to remain better placed from a risk – reward perspective, trading at a slight premium to historical average multiples while mid and small caps are trading at multiples which are still higher than their long terms average. Delivery of earnings becomes even more critical especially for mid and small caps.

Do you expect earnings upgrades in the pharma and discretionary sectors? Do you expect 15 percent earnings growth in FY26 after the anticipated mid-teen growth in the current fiscal year?

Given that the corporate earnings delivery in H1FY25 has been muted, the consensus earnings growth estimates for FY25 now stands in mid - single digits, while expectations remain of mid-teens earnings growth in FY26. This deceleration in earnings in FY25 can be attributed to the slowdown in consumption (especially urban consumption), near term deceleration in government capex, and credit growth easing from 16-17% to ~11-12% at present. From here on, the trajectory of earnings growth in FY26 would depend to a great extent on the revival of demand and resumption of government spending. In that context, the key driver for earnings in FY26 would have to be topline growth as most of the margin levers has been largely exhausted.

Disclaimer: The views and investment tips expressed by investment experts on Moneycontrol.com are their own and not those of the website or its management. Moneycontrol.com advises users to check with certified experts before taking any investment decisions.
data.author: MoneyControl

data.title: Daily Voice: 100% FDI in insurance unlikely to significantly change competitive landscape, says Manish Gunwani of Bandhan AMC
data.description:
Manish Gunwani is the Head – Equities at Bandhan AMC

According to Manish Gunwani of Bandhan AMC, the increase in FDI limit to 100% (from 74% earlier) for insurance sector is unlikely to significantly change competitive landscape. Most of the incumbents have very strong brand and distribution, he reasoned.

He believes the budget does provide a fairly strong boost to urban consumption via tax cuts. Also, "since fiscal deficit is lower than expected it may help reduce interest rates which will further aid urban consumption," said Manish with over 27 years of experience in equity research as well as fund management. He is the Head – Equities at Bandhan AMC.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Will you give a 10/10 for the budget, and why?

I would give it 8/10 as while significant stimulus to middle-class, reasonable growth in infrastructure spending and broadly conservative estimates are big positives, the overall expenditure growth is limited – it may need to be combined with other steps like monetary easing to help growth.

Do you think the budget has done enough to boost urban consumption, which was a major concern for the equity markets?

Yes the budget does provide a fairly strong boost to urban consumption via tax cuts. Also since fiscal deficit is lower than expected it may help reduce interest rates which will further aid urban consumption.

Do you foresee a revival in private capex, especially after significant personal tax relief?

The budget via boosting consumption should help in increasing capacity utilisation which should in turn incentivise private capex. However, private capex is subject to many other moving parts as well including global growth, interest rates etc.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

What are the three biggest positives and three biggest negatives that have emerged from the Union Budget?

Positives
1) Tax cuts for helping consumption
2) Reasonable growth in infrastructure spending
3) Broadly conservative estimates

Negatives
1) Overall expenditure growth limited
2) Strategic divestment stance not clear
3) Limited steps to accelerate labour intensive manufacturing

Do you think 100% FDI in insurance will significantly change the competitive landscape?

It is unlikely as most of the incumbents have very strong brand and distribution.

What is the main reason the government hasn't focused much on capex in the budget?

If compared to revised estimates the numbers are reasonable. The growth multiplier may be better with consumption stimulus.

Which sectors would you consider investing in after the budget?

Overall we feel structurally segments where India’s white collar workforce is employed are globally competitive and this will aid urban, affluent consumption – the budget has in general aided these segments.

Disclaimer: The views and investment tips expressed by investment experts on Moneycontrol.com are their own and not those of the website or its management. Moneycontrol.com advises users to check with certified experts before taking any investment decisions.

data.title: Trading Plan: Will Nifty climb toward 23,900, Bank Nifty surpass 50,500?
data.description:
Nifty Trading Plan

Both Nifty 50 and Bank Nifty bounced back smartly, forming long bullish candlestick patterns on the daily charts, with a positive bias in the momentum indicator RSI and VIX hitting a one-month low on February 4. Hence, as long as the index sustains above 23,600 (200-day EMA), the upward journey toward the 23,900–24,000 zone is likely in the upcoming sessions. However, in case of a correction, 23,550 is the immediate support, followed by 23,350 as the key support. The Bank Nifty may also extend its upward journey toward the 50,500–51,000 zone as long as it holds 50,000 (the high of budget day) as support, according to experts.

On Tuesday, February 4, the Nifty 50 surged by 378 points (1.62%) to close at 23,739, while the Bank Nifty soared by 947 points (1.93%) to 50,158, with market breadth favouring bulls. A total of 1,797 shares saw buying interest, against 764 shares that declined on the NSE.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Nifty Outlook and Strategy

Ashish Kyal, CMT, Founder and CEO of Waves Strategy Advisors

In the previous session, Nifty opened with a gap up and continued to gain in the second half. Investors were relieved after news about the US pausing planned tariffs on Canada and Mexico. Now, all focus is on the RBI policy meet, which is going to happen later this week on February 7.

On the daily chart, Nifty has completed its journey toward the upper Bollinger Bands after reversing from the lower bands in just 8 trading sessions. Prices have broken out of it, and now, with follow-up buying, we can expect a move toward the previous swing high, which is near the 24,200 levels. Also, since January 28, prices have protected the previous day’s low on a closing basis, which is a bullish sign.

In summary, the overall trend for Nifty is positive. For now, a break above 23,800 can continue the bullish momentum in the index with targets of 24,930, followed by 24,200. Any breach below 23,530 will be the first sign of concern.

Key Resistance: 24,200

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Key Support: 23,530

Strategy: Long positions can be created above 23,800 with a stop-loss at 23,700, targeting 23,930, followed by 24,200.

Dhupesh Dhameja, Derivative Research Analyst at Samco Securities

The Nifty index continued its bullish trajectory, notching a strong breakout above its previous swing high, signaling robust buying interest. Intraday dips attracted consistent accumulation, reinforcing market resilience and investor confidence. The index has successfully breached both the 50- and 200-day EMAs, further validating the bullish momentum. Adding to the positive setup, the RSI (Relative Strength Index) remains firmly above 50, while price action sustains above the 20-day EMA, strengthening the case for a continued rally.

The index is now testing its descending trendline resistance, requiring a decisive breakout confirmation to unlock the next leg of gains. The 23,800–23,850 zone remains a formidable resistance, reinforced by heavy Call writing at these levels.

Options market data suggests that strong Put writing at 23,300–23,500 is establishing a solid support base, hinting at a "buy-on-dips" approach from market participants. Immediate resistance remains stacked between 23,800 and 24,000, with any breakout likely to trigger a sharp rally. From a broader perspective, Nifty’s price action suggests that bullish momentum remains intact, especially with leading index stocks displaying strong reversals, further bolstering the uptrend. A decisive breakout above 23,800 could pave the way for a swift move toward 24,000–24,100, signaling a renewed bullish phase and opening the doors for a sustained upside run.

Key Resistance: 23,800, 24,000, 24,100

Key Support: 23,500, 23,300, 23,000

Strategy: Traders can implement a Bull Put Spread strategy (selling a Put option with a higher strike and buying a Put option with a lower strike of the same expiry).

Preeti K Chabra, Founder of Trade Delta

Overall, the Nifty 50 has been making higher lows and higher highs since the low of 22,786 made on January 27, except for the surprise negative candle made on February 3 due to the global event of the tariff announcement. It closed above the crucial 200 EMA level of 23,619, with shorter moving averages trending upward, suggesting bullish momentum. Nifty has closed above the important trend change level of 23,632, which is the earlier swing high. On the weekly chart, Nifty is trading above the channel breakout with a close above the 50-week EMA level of 23,434.

India VIX, often referred to as the “fear gauge,” is trading in the range of 14, the lowest level since January 3, providing much comfort to bulls. Nifty is trading at an RSI of 56.98 and is trending upward, suggesting bullish momentum. On the options front, we see massive unwinding of both In The Money (ITM) and Out of Money (OTM) Calls, suggesting a bullish outlook. We see Nifty heading toward the zone of 23,850–23,900. To take advantage of the bullish scenario, we can deploy a low-cost Butterfly at 23,900, the point where we receive maximum profit.

Key Resistance: 23,777, 23,888

Key Support: 23,632, 23,350

Strategy: Deploy a Butterfly Spread for potential gains from the bullish outlook in Nifty.

Traders use this strategy when they expect the price of an underlying asset to increase in the future. It involves buying a Call option at a lower strike, selling 2 Call options at a middle strike, and buying 1 Call option at a higher strike. It has the benefit of limited risk, high profit potential, and relatively low upfront cost.

Bank Nifty - Outlook and Positioning

Ashish Kyal, CMT, Founder and CEO of Waves Strategy Advisors

In the previous session, Bank Nifty witnessed a sharp rise and yet again touched the 50,000 mark. On the daily chart, prices finally broke the Double Bottom pattern and also gave a close above the neckline, which is near the 46,700 level. Also, since January 27, not a single candle has closed below the previous day's low, suggesting that bulls have tightened their grip with each passing day.

The recent rise has retraced almost 38.2% of the prior fall that started from December 2024. We expect it to retrace 50% of the fall, which is near the 50,795 levels. Additionally, in the previous session, not a single hourly candle has closed below the previous candle’s low, which is a bullish signal. In summary, the trend for Bank Nifty has changed to the positive side. A break above 50,250 can lift the price higher toward 50,500, followed by 50,795. On the downside, 48,900 is the nearest support.

Key Resistance: 50,795

Key Support: 48,900

Strategy: Long positions can be created above 50,250 with targets of 50,500, followed by 50,795, and a stop-loss at 50,000 levels.

Dhupesh Dhameja, Derivative Research Analyst at Samco Securities

The Nifty Bank index maintains its bullish momentum, posting a strong breakout above the neckline of its double-bottom chart pattern, signaling renewed buying interest. Intraday dips attracted consistent accumulation, highlighting market confidence and robust institutional participation. The index has successfully surpassed its psychological barrier at 50,000, further reinforcing bullish sentiment. Additionally, the RSI remains comfortably above 50, while price action continues to hold above the 20-day EMA, strengthening the outlook for further upside.

However, the index now approaches a critical hurdle at its 50- and 200-day EMA resistance, requiring a decisive breakout to sustain the ongoing rally. At present, Nifty Bank is navigating a key resistance zone between 50,300 and 50,400, where heavy Call writing activity suggests a tough supply zone.

Meanwhile, options market data indicates strong Put additions at 49,000–49,700, reinforcing a solid support base and confirming a buy-on-dips strategy among market participants. A decisive move above 50,400 could unlock a strong upside potential, with the index likely to rally toward 51,000–51,200, reinforcing the ongoing bullish trend and keeping momentum intact.

Key Resistance: 50,500, 51,000, 51,300

Key Support: 49,700, 49,500, 49,000

Strategy: Traders can consider long Bank Nifty February Futures if the price crosses above 50,400–50,450, setting a stop-loss below 49,950. Profit-taking can be considered once the index reaches 50,900–51,100.

Preeti K Chabra, Founder of Trade Delta

Bank Nifty is now trading above an important trend change level of 50,009, which is the earlier swing high, and closed above the upward-sloping trendline. Bank Nifty is on the verge of surpassing the crucial 200 EMA level of 50,200, which will further add momentum to Bank Nifty. On the weekly chart, Bank Nifty is trading above the channel breakout with a close above the 50-week EMA level of 49,840.

Bank Nifty is trading at an RSI of 55.06, with the trend on the upside, suggesting bullish momentum. On the options front, we see massive unwinding of In The Money (ITM) Call options, indicating a bullish outlook. To take advantage of the bullish momentum, we advise traders to be long on Bank Nifty with a buy-on-dips outlook.

Key Resistance: 50,300, 50,600

Key Support: 49,650, 49,300

Strategy: Buy Bank Nifty Futures in the zone of 49,650 for the target of 50,600 with a stop-loss at 49,300.

Disclaimer: The views and investment tips expressed by experts on Moneycontrol are their own and not those of the website or its management. Moneycontrol advises users to check with certified experts before taking any investment decisions.
